<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>A big new genetic <a href="https://www.colorado.edu/today/2021/05/27/want-reduce-your-depression-risk-wake-hour-earlier?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">study</a> published in the journal JAMA Psychiatry concludes that waking up just one hour earlier could reduce a person’s risk of major depression by nearly a quarter.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRIME
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/fbi-international-authorities-arrest-hundreds-encrypted-messaging-app-sting?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Happens When the FBI Gets Into Your Pants?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/fbi-international-authorities-arrest-hundreds-encrypted-messaging-app-sting" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="FBI classified info" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=447 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/WoDqyh1EyxRR1LYsTi/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="FBI classified info" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/WoDqyh1EyxRR1LYsTi/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For almost three years, criminals used a network of encrypted devices to <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/06/08/1004332551/drug-rings-platform-operation-trojan-shield-anom-operation-greenlight?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">share the dirty details</a> of their smuggling and money laundering operations. If their messages about stuffing cocaine into pineapples and cans of tuna ever fell into authorities' hands, they believed, the incriminating information could be wiped from the encrypted devices they were using.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, they were duped.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The FBI was in cahoots with the developer of the device, called "Anom," the whole time, and yesterday announced a series of successful busts and 800+ arrests under the code name Operation Trojan Shield. They also seized...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Eight tons of cocaine and 22 tons of cannabis</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>55 luxury vehicles</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>250 firearms</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>$48+ million worth of various currencies and cryptocurrencies</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">How it happened</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 2018, the FBI <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/world/australia/operation-trojan-horse-anom.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">recruited</a> a former distributor of a different encrypted network that had just gotten busted. The engineer was working on a new service, Anom, that stripped mobile phones of their normal functions and disguised a secure messaging app to look like a calculator. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In exchange for a reduced sentence and $120k, the engineer gave the FBI a master key to access and save Anom messages. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the FBI <a href="https://apnews.com/article/europe-technology-a6ac691e26be2efc6e2f4a6974117536?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">took down</a> other encrypted communication services, more criminals started to DM using Anom's platform. The FBI also helped spread Anom by distributing devices to 300+ gangs across 100 countries through middlemen. One Australian fugitive, Hakan Ayik, aka the "Facebook gangster," was given an Anom device by undercover agents and, after recommending it to many associates, unwittingly <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-57397779?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">became</a> the FBI's top influencer. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Europol officials called it "one of the largest and most sophisticated law enforcement operations to date in the fight against encrypted criminal activities." Still, Anom represented just a fraction of criminal communications.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/propublica-estimates-richest-25-individuals-pay-34-tax-rate?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Breaking: Billionaires Don’t Pay a Lot in Taxes
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Okay, we knew that before...but now it's backed up by 15+ years' worth of IRS tax return data from thousands of America's wealthiest individuals, <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/the-secret-irs-files-trove-of-never-before-seen-records-reveal-how-the-wealthiest-avoid-income-tax?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made public</a> yesterday by investigative journalism outlet ProPublica.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">ProPublica estimates that America's richest 25 people paid a cumulative $13.6 billion in income taxes between 2014 and 2018, a span during which their collective wealth increased $400+ billion, for a "true tax rate" that was just 3.4%. Paying the lowest rates were Warren Buffett (0.1%), Jeff Bezos (0.98%), Michael Bloomberg (1.3%), and Elon Musk (3.27%).</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Reminder: Most billionaires' wealth comes from assets like stock and property. Those gains aren't taxed until they are sold.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Compared to the broader population, billionaires' tax bills have not kept pace with their growing bank accounts. For every $100 gained, Bezos paid just $1.09 while the typical US household paid $160.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">ProPublica is still combing through the IRS data to explore how billionaires avoided those taxes. But it'll have a magnifying glass on its own back after the IRS said it's investigating the big leak.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>These revelations will lead to louder calls to reform the US tax code.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/spotify-amazon-sites-experience-outages?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Internet's Rocky Tuesday Morning
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Stress coffee drinking" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/8ZeiHZ3qV5LvDsTQh3/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Stress coffee drinking" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/8ZeiHZ3qV5LvDsTQh3/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If your AM routine includes listening to Spotify, reading the New York Times, and browsing Amazon...it certainly didn't yesterday. For up to an hour Tuesday morning, all of those websites, plus CNN, the BBC, Hulu, HBO Max, and many more, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/06/08/major-websites-experience-outages-including-new-york-times-cnn-amazon-web-services/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">were down</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Why? Because Fastly, those websites' "content delivery network," experienced a glitch. To get technical, Fastly tweeted that it identified "a service configuration that triggered disruptions across our POPs [points of presence] globally." </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Now, in English:</strong></span><span> If the internet were a play, Fastly would be one member of its stage crew. It helps keep websites running by facilitating page and file loading. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fastly's domino effect of destruction isn't the first time an outage revealed the fragility of the internet's infrastructure: In 2017, one coding error on Amazon's cloud computing service caused Medium, Coursera, Slack, and other sites to temporarily <a href="https://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2017/03/02/aws-outage-that-broke-the-internet-caused-by-mistyped-command?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shut down</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>One hour offline may not sound like a lot, but it can translate to <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/0d5b9430-750b-44b7-b238-6e2160c3c591?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">millions of dollars</a> in advertising revenue and e-commerce losses for affected sites.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>More than 25% of shoppers at Levi’s have a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/health-coronavirus-pandemic-voting-rights-lifestyle-business-1c8e43118ef0d01d2e79475fb61c9dcc?campaign_id=4&emc=edit_dk_20210608&instance_id=32489&nl=dealbook&regi_id=83342785&segment_id=60140&te=1&user_id=6e8f5c5256f51c870f4df90ca819260d" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">different size</a> today than before the pandemic, according to CEO Chip Bergh. He called the number of people with new sizes “pretty staggering.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> “The stimmies have been fantastic for us in terms of getting into the communities.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We did it! IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig used the word “<a href="https://twitter.com/RichardRubinDC/status/1402282138234458117?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stimmies</a>” in place of the more IRS-sounding “stimulus checks” during his testimony on Capitol Hill yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read:</strong> If you give a lobster enough THC, will it notice that it is boiling to death? (<a href="https://cannabitch.substack.com/p/thc-the-high-crustaceans?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Jackie Bryant</a>)</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/kanye-west-gaps-cobranded-jacket-sells-hours?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Better, Faster, Stronger, Bluer, Puffier
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Gap Yeezy Jacket" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MzgwL2dhcF95ZWV6eV9qYWNrZXQucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Gap</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just in time for Kanye West's 44th birthday and summer, Gap and Yeezy <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/08/business/yeezy-gap-first-release/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unveiled</a> the first product of their partnership yesterday: the jacket you see above. The specs...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Retails for $200</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Self-described as "round"</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Cannot be closed (no buttons, zippers, etc.)</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Most of West's reported $6.6 billion fortune comes from his Yeezy brand, whose partnerships with Adidas and Gap are worth up to a combined $4.7 billion, according to UBS. We're still in the early innings of the 10-year deal with Gap, but it's looking promising: Would-be buyers experienced long wait times to place their preorders, while others were hit with a "sold out" message.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Cool marketing: </strong>To promote the release, the jacket's <a href="https://twitter.com/PhotosOfKanye/status/1402141559546654720?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">being projected</a> old-school-cinema-style throughout NYC, LA, and Kanye's own Chi City.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>A previous verison of this story said that the jacket was sold out.</em></p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Everyone knows Uber prices are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/technology/farewell-millennial-lifestyle-subsidy.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sky-high right now</a>. But...how high?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Managing editor Neal Freyman requested an UberX from his Manhattan apartment to JFK yesterday around 2pm. How much does the ride cost? (<em>Price Is Right </em>rules apply...you can’t go over.)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">  <img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MzczL3ViZXJfcmlkZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24ifQ==" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 405px;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWhat Happens When the FBI Gets Into Your Pants?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/08/fbi-international-authorities-arrest-hundreds-encrypted-messaging-app-sting\" style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor almost three years, criminals used a network of encrypted devices to \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/06/08/1004332551/drug-rings-platform-operation-trojan-shield-anom-operation-greenlight?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshare the dirty details\u003c/a\u003e of their smuggling and money laundering operations. If their messages about stuffing cocaine into pineapples and cans of tuna ever fell into authorities' hands, they believed, the incriminating information could be wiped from the encrypted devices they were using.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWell, they were duped.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe FBI was in cahoots with the developer of the device, called \"Anom,\" the whole time, and yesterday announced a series of successful busts and 800+ arrests under the code name Operation Trojan Shield. They also seized...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEight tons of cocaine and 22 tons of cannabis\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e55 luxury vehicles\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e250 firearms\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e$48+ million worth of various currencies and cryptocurrencies\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHow it happened\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 2018, the FBI \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/world/australia/operation-trojan-horse-anom.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erecruited\u003c/a\u003e a former distributor of a different encrypted network that had just gotten busted. The engineer was working on a new service, Anom, that stripped mobile phones of their normal functions and disguised a secure messaging app to look like a calculator. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn exchange for a reduced sentence and $120k, the engineer gave the FBI a master key to access and save Anom messages. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the FBI \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/europe-technology-a6ac691e26be2efc6e2f4a6974117536?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etook down\u003c/a\u003e other encrypted communication services, more criminals started to DM using Anom's platform. The FBI also helped spread Anom by distributing devices to 300+ gangs across 100 countries through middlemen. One Australian fugitive, Hakan Ayik, aka the \"Facebook gangster,\" was given an Anom device by undercover agents and, after recommending it to many associates, unwittingly \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-57397779?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebecame\u003c/a\u003e the FBI's top influencer. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eEuropol officials called it \"one of the largest and most sophisticated law enforcement operations to date in the fight against encrypted criminal activities.\" Still, Anom represented just a fraction of criminal communications.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBreaking: Billionaires Don’t Pay a Lot in Taxes\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOkay, we knew that before...but now it's backed up by 15+ years' worth of IRS tax return data from thousands of America's wealthiest individuals, \u003ca href=\"https://www.propublica.org/article/the-secret-irs-files-trove-of-never-before-seen-records-reveal-how-the-wealthiest-avoid-income-tax?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade public\u003c/a\u003e yesterday by investigative journalism outlet ProPublica.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eProPublica estimates that America's richest 25 people paid a cumulative $13.6 billion in income taxes between 2014 and 2018, a span during which their collective wealth increased $400+ billion, for a \"true tax rate\" that was just 3.4%. Paying the lowest rates were Warren Buffett (0.1%), Jeff Bezos (0.98%), Michael Bloomberg (1.3%), and Elon Musk (3.27%).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eReminder: Most billionaires' wealth comes from assets like stock and property. Those gains aren't taxed until they are sold.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eCompared to the broader population, billionaires' tax bills have not kept pace with their growing bank accounts. For every $100 gained, Bezos paid just $1.09 while the typical US household paid $160.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eProPublica is still combing through the IRS data to explore how billionaires avoided those taxes. But it'll have a magnifying glass on its own back after the IRS said it's investigating the big leak.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThese revelations will lead to louder calls to reform the US tax code.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf your AM routine includes listening to Spotify, reading the New York Times, and browsing Amazon...it certainly didn't yesterday. For up to an hour Tuesday morning, all of those websites, plus CNN, the BBC, Hulu, HBO Max, and many more, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/06/08/major-websites-experience-outages-including-new-york-times-cnn-amazon-web-services/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewere down\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhy? Because Fastly, those websites' \"content delivery network,\" experienced a glitch. To get technical, Fastly tweeted that it identified \"a service configuration that triggered disruptions across our POPs [points of presence] globally.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNow, in English:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e If the internet were a play, Fastly would be one member of its stage crew. It helps keep websites running by facilitating page and file loading. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFastly's domino effect of destruction isn't the first time an outage revealed the fragility of the internet's infrastructure: In 2017, one coding error on Amazon's cloud computing service caused Medium, Coursera, Slack, and other sites to temporarily \u003ca href=\"https://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2017/03/02/aws-outage-that-broke-the-internet-caused-by-mistyped-command?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshut down\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eOne hour offline may not sound like a lot, but it can translate to \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/0d5b9430-750b-44b7-b238-6e2160c3c591?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emillions of dollars\u003c/a\u003e in advertising revenue and e-commerce losses for affected sites.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
